See pic for color and pour. Aromas of citrus-y cobwebs. Taste is dry and lightly bitter. Some funk. Crushable yet high boost. Great stuff.

Hazy yellow color... Aroma of brett, lemon, grains, citra hops... Flavor is pure brett funk, with lots of citra hop notes, tropical fruit sweetness initially with dry earthiness on finish... Great beer

Nice! Lots of Brett funk with a hoppy finish. Not for amateurs. Lots and lots of Brett. No sour .

Bottle @ home. Hazed straw colored beer with a tall white head. Intense passion fruit, pineapple, lime, and lemon zest. Nice funk in there as well, kind of earthy and grassy. A touch of golden apple, melon, and some tangy grape. Really nice (though mild) stone fruit as well. Pleasant acidity, some mild bitterness, and just a touch of biscuity malts. Such great fruit character throughout.

Hazy amber/gold color; Medium body; Aroma of yeast, funk, floral, & citrus; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, funk/brett, floral hops, citrus, and some salt/spice; Dry finish; Fairly high carbonation; Nicely balanced; Good one!

P: A hazy yellow straw color with a thin head. S: The salt is pretty strong, along with some minerals, malt, yeast, and hint of hops (pineapple and pine) T: Straight lemons and mangos with brett. Well balanced beer with the hops and brett. The salt isnt very noticeable, and thats a good thin. M: Highly carbonated with medium body. O: A very nice beer, but just like every prairie beer it hits the wallet.

Awesome! Bottle from bottle caps. Pours cloudy yellow with tons of light foamy lacing and lots of lacing. Nose is salty and some lemon. Flavours of lemon, salt, grapefruit, dough. Taste light bitter, light tart, light sweet and light salt. Full somewhat silky body with lively carbonation. Nice!

From draft, pours cloudy pale gold. Thin but persistent head maintained by steady effervescence. Smells of lemon and very faint hops. Taste is tart and salty, with back-end farmhouse wild funk. Mild body that leaves tongue slightly dehydrated. Reminds me of a grown-up gose. Would drink again.

Bottle from Total Wine, Sacramento. Pours dirty blonde with a huge foamy white head and an earthy fruit aroma. There is a fruity light malt flavor with a dry bitter finish. Slightly salty and quite tasty.

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate pineapple, lemon, florals, straw, funk, faint cotton candy, and a touch of pepper. It pours a hazy/cloudy dull golden-orange with a two finger white head that fades to a thin film outlined by a thicker ring. There is some soapy webbing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with moderate citrus, pineapple, and a touch of cotton candy. The finish has light-moderate lemon peel, florals, grass, and a touch of pepper. Its light-medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

Bottle pour into New Belgium "globe" glass: Hazy, bright golden straw yellow with ample rocky white foam. Its got bright lemon, wonderful Brett funk, some tropical floral notes. Some apricot, light fruit coctail syrup, toasty bread crust and biscuit with mild tartness and subtle spice. It finishes with a powdery bitterness that lingers. Very nice flavor but I feel the palate is a little thin.

16.9 oz bottle from Binnys South Loop (Chicago, IL). Pours a hazy golden yellow hue, a decent haziness that still allows for a jewelry glow allure. Bigger cakey brighter white head atop is sizable, cakey and large. Good retention and size, nice enough lacing throughout is spidery. Aromas are funky and dry, a bit dank and earthy with horseblanket, cobwebs and a bit of pineapple goodness. Florals, a bit of citrus and floral elements, subtle tropical fruit grows slowly as the hops come into the fold more. Dry grain, straw, grapefruit rind is fruity, pulpy and pithy. Some wafts of tropical fruit. Alluring as it settles. Initial is lighter end of the fold, just a touch of bready girth. Pineapple and funk meet mellow bitterness, pithy citrus, firmer pineapple juice sweet and a bit tart with subtle tropical fruit. Mellow horseblanket, dry straw and a bit of cool smoothed out fruit. The bitterness picks up a touch into the backend, the funk works well as a middling yet sufficient tropical alllure, mango and faint bubblegum meet that tart pineapple, earth and bready malts. A bit dry, bitter and funky as we round the corner with smoothed out tropical elements from the middle rollingover. I dig this. The hop element adds complexity but isnt overwhelming. The funk is on point, earthy and dank without overwhelming either. The elements seem integrated well with nice tropical elements, tart and fruity, as the backend gets a bit dry and bitter as we finish up. Mellow grains, earth. This drinks really nice and I dig it. The trendy hops add life and flavor while the wild yeast allows for complexity. The crisper light body makes it quite drinkable. Nice stuff!

Draft at Lizardville in Copley. Poured a beautiful orange-yellow cloud into a tulip with solid head and lace. The aroma is a brett bomb with hints of orange, lemon zest, and starfruit. The taste is at first the citrus bites but then comes the brett funkiness on the backend. It finishes well balanced with the brett funk, slight dankness, and citrus zests. Solid carb and mouth. Just a beautiful beer on draft.

500 ml bottle from Supermarket Liquors. Hazy orange appearance with a nice, lacy and lingering white head. Fresh aroma of juicy citrus, tropical fruits, light funky yeast, light hop spice, earth, grass and a touch of black pepper. Similar flavor, adding a mild zesty hop bitterness and a light tart finish. Medium body with a light dry feel. Refreshing and easy to drink. Tasty beverage fo sho.

Bottle. Pour is very cloudy pale yellow with a large white head. Aroma is funky and lemony with hints of orange and rock. Flavor is crisp and light with loads of dry Brett intermixed with distant grapefruit and light hop resin. Not loving this. Its dry and easy to drink but seems a little out of balance to me. The hops are sharp and dry but so is the Brett. The citrus components are light and distant. I could see this being more appealing if tried again.

Hops Hill, Brooklyn tap: Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is nice bits of funk, citrus fruits, and more tropical fruits and salt (haha nevermind salt doesnt have a smell). I also didnt get any salt in the taste, but then again, I was eating some chips while drinking this beer. Taste was pretty dope. Nice combination of the brett with the tropical fruit. Feels light for its size and that is always a plus.
Bottle poured into stemware -- Pretty straw/golden pour. Very nice Saison, very crisp. The citrus hops add to the refreshing finish. Two unlike things balanced into a great beer.
Apricot pour, small white head. Aroma of peach, citrus, brett, dried fruit. Flavor of peach, apricot, tartness, hay, barnyard, citrus and yeast. Damn.

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden yellow, medium white head, slow to dissipate and laces well. Aroma is initially a bit sulphuric, but that fades fast leaving a tropical dank citra note with bretty funk, basement, musty. Flavor is juicy, fairly dry with a hint of tartness and medium funk, lots of tropical dank cat pissy notes along with basement and horse blanket. Medium plus body, creamy in the mouth, brett and passionfruit linger on the tongue. No hint of the 8%. This is a damn fine beer; I just wish it was 5% :)

Bottle at home. Pour is hazy golden with a big white head and sticky lacing. Big bretty, herbal, band-aid, tropical fruity, some weed notes, biscuity, pineapple and papaya in the aroma. Taste is very juicy, herbal, medicinal, some grass notes, lots of pineapple, lemons, some herbs, and white pepper with a tart finish. Full mouthfeel with high carbonation. Reminds me of Merica. Really tasty.

The beer pours a cloudy yellow color with a large white head that fades somewhat slowly. Cloudy golden orange pour with a profuse and creamy off white head. Very nice aroma, tropical fruit, subtle lemongrass, pineapple, phenolic spice, and bright citrus. Bottle. Pours murky yellow/gold. Aroma is pale malt, wheat, funk, barnyard notes, and some floral notes. Flavor is dry and fruity with some noticeable funk, light toast, and some smooth, light hop notes. Medium body.

From a bottle at the Wicked Weed Funk Asheville Fest 2015. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Light tart citrus flavors. Smooth and easy drinking.

500ml bottle. It has a nice citrus and tropial character all around, some tartness, good stuff.
Smooth mellow funk to the aroma. Super cloudy pale tan light lasting head. Very smooth with very soft wheat approachable funk. Ballanced funky saison.
